{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3322264,"name":"","username":"Theeagle49","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/cab0a1/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-02T23:13:49.587Z","cooked":"

Our team is using vortex motors on SDS MK4is this year for our drivetrain. When we returned from a match we found that a swerve module wheel wasnt turning right and saw that the pinion was angled away from the gear it was driving and was not loose or otherwise able to be moved by hand. We replaced this motor and when spinning by hand felt slightly more resistance than normal and heard a very quiet sound that to us sounded like something was lightly spinning against something stationary. When we opened the motor we found that two of the tapped holes for the m3 screws were gone and there were many large cracks through the faceplate.

We had the same happen today. I’m actually currently working on a writeup that details all of our issues with our NEO Vortexes and Spark Flexes at our Week 1.
Ours was the drive motor in a Mk4i, and was shielded inside the module as well as by the robot’s belly plate.

Not sure if this is a related issue to the faceplate cracks, but figured I would share our experience / issue from our comp this past weekend.

While we were checking obvious screws (MK4i-to-SparkFlex, SparkFlex-to-Motor, 8mm shaft retention, etc), after our first playoff match our pit crew noticed that the 8mm shafts were easily moveable (i.e. flexing side-to-side) and all of the toothed retainer clips were gone from the pinion gears. They replaced the clips and immediately flipped the bot onto it’s side to start checking / tightening screws - figuring that the shaft retention screws had come loose under all of the load they were experiencing (we had locktited those when we assembled the motors). All of the “obvious” screws were still tight. We then noticed that one of the tiny housing screws (circled in red in the picture) was gone. Turns out that many of the other similar screws were loose on the motors (some by nearly a full turn) which allows the faceplate to flex away from the motor body and allows the shaft to flex as well. We replaced the missing one and tightened the ones that we could - some were stripped and could not be tightened. The ones that were able to be tightened made the shafts rigid again. However where one was stripped, the shaft was able to still flex. I’m not going to blame our playoff losses on this issue, but our mobility was definitely impacted negatively which didn’t help. Granted, we had ran those motors hard for several weeks of practice prior to comp and during comp without issue and would’ve absolutely had those screws on our checklists had we known how important they were.

We’re going to contact REV to see if we can get a torque spec for those screws and see what we can do about the motors where the screws are stripped.

Edit: I should clarify that we have not yet pulled the suspect motors to do a closer inspection. It still looks to me like that those screws I mentioned only hold the plastic cowling, so it could just be coincidental that when we tightened them it made the shafts more rigid. We’ll know more tomorrow when we get back in the shop.

image966×714 62.1 KB

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2024-03-04T15:43:00.424Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":889,"readers_count":888,"score":192.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":456992,"topic_slug":"psa-vortex-faceplate-cracks","display_username":"Matt Middleton","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40501,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Chief Cat Herder / Bottle Washer"},"post_url":"/t/psa-vortex-faceplate-cracks/456992/5","custom_user_title":"Chief Cat Herder / Bottle Washer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3323359,"name":"REV Robotics Co-founder & CEO","username":"Greg_Needel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/greg_needel/{size}/244586_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-04T15:51:33.096Z","cooked":"

I would like to see photos of how these motors are installed on the robot and any videos of matches in which you think they failed during.

In our testing during the development of the Vortex, we saw this issue, and made some changes to the casting, which improved its strength. The only way we were able to crack the face plate during our internal testing was through a very large direct impact on the can of the motor (think 5lb dead blow full force swing). This is why I am curious about where and how they are mounted.

After one weekend of play its obvious this game is very harsh on robots, I know we found things inside my team’s bot that got bent or broken from impacts that normally would have been fine.

If you could please either post information here or if you want more specific support please email us, so we can see if we can collect some data to give guidance to teams who might be using them in similar situations.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2024-03-04T15:51:33.096Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":18,"reads":830,"readers_count":829,"score":431.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":456992,"topic_slug":"psa-vortex-faceplate-cracks","display_username":"REV Robotics Co-founder & CEO","primary_group_name":"REV","flair_name":"REV","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/d/b/db93216ec14c273ae2ca04aa396186c0461d0620.png","flair_bg_color":"F05A28","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":55,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"REV Robotics","title_is_group":false,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":11}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":511,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/psa-vortex-faceplate-cracks/456992/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":11},{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":12,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3323400,"name":"Matt Middleton","username":"Mattmidd630","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mattmidd630/{size}/266313_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-04T16:35:02.767Z","cooked":"

Greg, will do. In our case, they were installed as the drive motors on SDS Mk4i modules (standard mount with SparkFlexes). We’re using the higher configuration as far as the chassis-tube-to-swerve so the motors were well off the ground and we have full polycarb “skirts” to within 3/8" from the carpet, so nothing got under our robot. We did suffer some very hard collisions in match play, but I wouldn’t think that would equal the kind of forces on the can that you mentioned.

Ultimately we want to better understand the situation ourselves and help you help other teams so that everyone can operate at their best. We appreciate your continued responsiveness and will contact you soon with our findings.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2024-03-04T16:35:02.767Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":784,"readers_count":783,"score":156.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":456992,"topic_slug":"psa-vortex-faceplate-cracks","display_username":"Matt Middleton","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":511,"username":"Greg_Needel","name":"REV Robotics Co-founder & CEO","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/greg_needel/{size}/244586_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40501,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Chief Cat Herder / Bottle Washer"},"post_url":"/t/psa-vortex-faceplate-cracks/456992/7","custom_user_title":"Chief Cat Herder / Bottle Washer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3324915,"name":"","username":"Theeagle49","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/cab0a1/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-05T21:22:37.171Z","cooked":"

I can’t get any good pictures of how they’re mounted on the robot, other than to state that they were the drive motors in MK4is with L3 gearing, and were protected by a large polycarb sheet from above so nothing would have hit the motors from above. We do leave the ground when intaking pretty commonly, but are pretty sure that nothing is hitting the casing from below. I think the big possible culprit might be the large impacts from coming back down when the front leaves the ground, but the steering neos and other motors on the robot have been fine thus far.

Here is a link to our TBA, I believe we noticed the first cracked motor after match 29 or 33, and the second after match 52.

The Blue Alliance

The Junkyard Dogs - Team 2106

FIRST Robotics Competition team from Goochland, Virginia, USA.

Following up. We confirmed at our meeting last night that unfortunately we also suffered fractured faceplates on 3 of our 4 drive motors. A few pictures below. We’ll be reaching out to REV to provide as much detail and we can in hopes that we can assist them in diagnosing the situation.

Robotics Co-founder & CEO","username":"Greg_Needel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/greg_needel/{size}/244586_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-06T16:13:44.739Z","cooked":"

Thanks for posting these, can you tell me what orientation the motors were relative to the crack on your MK4i.

For people watching this thread, the only reports we have seen of this are vortex on mk4i, and we are investigating the cause.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2024-03-17T20:00:56.173Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":668,"readers_count":667,"score":198.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":456992,"topic_slug":"psa-vortex-faceplate-cracks","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/b/3/b3171ac9bbd6000439fc761c47f80d3a946e4fe4.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/d/f/df5005000429bc7304faccf74140c4a2d80e8346.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":511,"username":"Greg_Needel","name":"REV Robotics Co-founder & CEO","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/greg_needel/{size}/244586_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53198,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"My views are mine and mine alone"},"post_url":"/t/psa-vortex-faceplate-cracks/456992/15","custom_user_title":"My views are mine and mine alone","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3336008,"name":"REV Robotics Co-founder & CEO","username":"Greg_Needel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/greg_needel/{size}/244586_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-18T16:00:14.475Z","cooked":"

Update on this, We have purchased and assembled and Mk4i as a test chassis and this week will be doing a bunch of testing to determine the cause of these failures.

Currently, Our working theories are related to the mounting of the motors to the SDS using a couple of standoffs where the motor is hanging from a small surface area instead of it being flush with a plate. That and the potential for the mounting screws to become loose which would potentially cause the can to be able to hit the chassis on big impacts.

There are several possible mitigation things such as running an end shaft bearing, 3d printing/machining a block to replace the spacers, etc.

As we get our testing done we will update with more information.

If you have had this happen to you, please send our support team and email so we can continue to compile reports and get information to try and get to the bottom of this. If you could include the following information it would be exceptionally useful

  • steering motor or drive motor
  • were there any signs that your mounting screws were loose
  • what wheels you are running (colson, tread, VEX, 3DP, etc)
  • what is your robots weight, and the footprint of your swerve drive
  • what gear ratio you are running in your modules
  • did they break after a noticeable impact during a specific match or was it discovered later? - If it is a match please tell us which one so we can watch video.

If it was the mounting to the flex controller that is a problem then i could see the swerve mounting would be a problem but the area that is breaking is the motor to the motor controller.

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2024-03-18T16:59:07.434Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":586,"readers_count":585,"score":137.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":456992,"topic_slug":"psa-vortex-faceplate-cracks","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":511,"username":"Greg_Needel","name":"REV Robotics Co-founder & CEO","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/greg_needel/{size}/244586_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53198,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"My views are mine and mine alone"},"post_url":"/t/psa-vortex-faceplate-cracks/456992/18","custom_user_title":"My views are mine and mine alone","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3336101,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-18T17:00:49.982Z","cooked":"

You have to be extra careful when you set a robot with SDS Mk4i swerve and NEO Vortex for either/both drive/steer on a cart that has supports to keep the wheels up in the air. It’s possible for the robot to actually rest on the ends of the motors. If they are spun, it can cause the robot to shift and might cause unusual loading in some cases. So, it would probably be good to think about this scenario and for teams to also report how they keep the robot with it’s wheels up on any cart.
